sourcing.instructions: Antimony can be sourced from chemical supply companies or online marketplaces specializing in metals. Tin is available at hardware stores or online metal suppliers. Titanium and zirconium can be sourced from specialty metal suppliers or online platforms that provide industrial metals.
steps: Antimony can be sourced from chemical supply companies or online marketplaces specializing in metals. Tin is available at hardware stores or online metal suppliers. Titanium and zirconium can be sourced from specialty metal suppliers or online platforms that provide industrial metals.

1. Wear appropriate safety gear (gloves, goggles, and mask) to handle metals safely. 2. Measure out each ingredient using a precision scale. 3. In a clean, dry container, combine 20 g of antimony, 40 g of tin, 30 g of titanium, and 60 g of zirconium. 4. Mix the powders thoroughly using a spatula or mechanical mixer until a homogeneous mixture is achieved.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Wear appropriate safety gear (gloves, goggles, and mask) to handle metals safely. 2. Measure out each ingredient using a precision scale. 3. In a clean, dry container, combine 20 g of antimony, 40 g of tin, 30 g of titanium, and 60 g of zirconium. 4. Mix the powders thoroughly using a spatula or mechanical mixer until a homogeneous mixture is achieved.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixed powder into a suitable crucible made of a material that can withstand high temperatures (e.g., graphite or ceramic). 2. Place the crucible in a furnace or high-temperature oven. 3. Heat the mixture to 950 °C (1742 °F) and maintain this temperature for 2 hours to ensure complete melting and alloying of the components.
heating.raw_text: 1. Transfer the mixed powder into a suitable crucible made of a material that can withstand high temperatures (e.g., graphite or ceramic). 2. Place the crucible in a furnace or high-temperature oven. 3. Heat the mixture to 950 °C (1742 °F) and maintain this temperature for 2 hours to ensure complete melting and alloying of the components.

steps: 1. After the heating duration, turn off the furnace and allow the crucible to cool to room temperature naturally. This process may take several hours. 2. Avoid rapid cooling to prevent cracking or stress in the material.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After the heating duration, turn off the furnace and allow the crucible to cool to room temperature naturally. This process may take several hours. 2. Avoid rapid cooling to prevent cracking or stress in the material.

steps: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the solid sample from the crucible. 2. Use a grinder or sanding tool to smooth out any rough edges and achieve the desired dimensions of 3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches. 3. Optionally, apply a sealant or protective coating to enhance surface durability and prevent oxidation. 4. Allow the sealant to cure as per the manufacturer’s instructions before handling the material further.
post_processing.raw_text: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the solid sample from the crucible. 2. Use a grinder or sanding tool to smooth out any rough edges and achieve the desired dimensions of 3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches. 3. Optionally, apply a sealant or protective coating to enhance surface durability and prevent oxidation. 4. Allow the sealant to cure as per the manufacturer’s instructions before handling the material further.
